f6_assessments.q0: This proposal is in line with the challenge setting. The proposer would work to reach out to over 2000 students in Northern Ghana to introduce them to cardano and the ecosystem. By doing so, students would be encouraged to participate in catalyst in whatever capacity they see fit, whether it be as proposers or community advisors. Meetups and conferences will be held to get the attention of the students, which I think can have a big impact on the future of cardano in Africa. Getting students interested in cardano from a younger age can inspire them to work towards making an impact on the ecosystem and their own communities. If the proposer reaches out to higher education students, then they will be likely to get involved with cardano sooner because they may have some technical knowledge that can be channeled towards developing catalyst proposals. I see this proposal checking all of the boxes for the challenge setting. (score given: 5)
f6_assessments.q1: Given the information provided, I think that the proposal will be successfully implemented. The proposers have the necessary skills to make this proposal come to life. For example, they have skills in IT services, lecturing, and blockchain education. All of these skills will be necessary to teach students in northern Ghana. With regards to the roadmap, I think that it is easy enough to follow. The proposers will use 1-3 months for the entire project, which includes reaching out to schools, teaching at least 1000 students, and training at least 200 students how to be community advisors. The proposal team plans to host 15 community events. I think that this number is pretty ambitious, but is achievable in the timeframe given. It would have been nice to see more of a detailed timeline, but I understand that the details haven’t been finalized because the proposers will reach out to the schools after being funded. The proposers did acknowledge that the schools might not get back to them in a timely manner, which could affect the progress of the proposal. However, they did also mention that they will reach out to the schools first, which should hopefully limit this issue. With regards to the budget, the proposers have provided a well thought-out list of costs that will be covered by the funding requested. It is very easy for me to see what funds are going where, which gives me confidence that the proposers understand what they will be doing. (score given: 4)
f6_assessments.q2: Given the information provided, I think that this proposal can be auditable, but it is lacking some key information. The proposers mentioned that they will have supervision from Wada, a well-known proposer group in this space, who frequently provide good reporting for auditability. Additionally, the metrics of success include mass on-boarding of students who will participate in catalyst, the number of local developers who learn Haskell, and the creation of dapps by those local developers. These are all very good goals, but I would also encourage the proposer to have some additional quantitative KPIs. For example, how many students who get involved with catalyst after attending a session would constitute success? How many developers? Unless the proposers maintain contact with the schools or students and can conduct some sort of retrospective survey, I imagine that it would be hard to check up on each participant to see whether they are involved with catalyst or not. My last question is, how will this information be shared with the cardano community? Is there a plan in place to present a post-completion report? What platform will be used? In the future, the proposers could address these questions to greatly strengthen the proposal. Even though this proposal is backed by Wada, more information could be provided for voters to better understand this proposal from an auditability perspective. Since I have so many questions regarding potential improvements to auditability, I can’t say for certain whether the proposal will be fully auditable in its current form. (score given: 3)
